Text: Congratulations on creating your Asmodee.net account! Your account gives you many rewards: new Heroes, cards, a starter deck, a gift of 3000 Valor points, and the first Quest free!

Text: At first the globe was dark, black as jet, with the moonlight gleaming on its surface. Then there came a faint glow and stir in the heart of it, and it held his eyes… —The Two Towers
Text_CN: At first the globe was dark, black as jet, with the moonlight gleaming on its surface. Then there came a faint glow and stir in the heart of it, and it held his eyes… —The Two Towers
Text_FR: At first the globe was dark, black as jet, with the moonlight gleaming on its surface. Then there came a faint glow and stir in the heart of it, and it held his eyes… —The Two Towers

Text: The Palantír is a bonus system. This wondrous object of mysterious ability grants rewards when you gaze into it. You spend a Palantír View each time you gaze into the Palantír. You then receive two rewards from the following possibilities: Valor Points; cards you do not own already; or new cosmetic items. Palantír Views are precious things. You can gain them through exceptional gameplay or through special boons bestowed upon you.
Text_CN: The Palantír is a bonus system. This wondrous object of mysterious ability grants rewards when you gaze into it. You spend a Palantír View each time you gaze into the Palantír. You then receive two rewards from the following possibilities: Valor Points; cards you do not own already; or new cosmetic items. Palantír Views are precious things. You can gain them through exceptional gameplay or through special boons bestowed upon you.

You can gain them through exceptional gameplay or through special boons bestowed upon you.

Text: Though he comes from humble beginnings, Samwise Gamgee rises to any challenge with unmatched bravery and determination. This pack is tailor-made for cleverness, helping you sneak past the watchful Eye of Sauron to claim victory through daring and stealth.
Text_CN: 虽然他出身低微，Samwise Gamgee 面对任何挑战都有无以伦比的勇气和决心 这个卡包专为机智的你定制，帮助你通过大胆和潜行逃过索伦之眼并获得胜利。
Text_FR: Though he comes from humble beginnings, Samwise Gamgee rises to any challenge with unmatched bravery and determination. This pack is tailor-made for cleverness, helping you sneak past the watchful Eye of Sauron to claim victory through daring and stealth.

Text: Faramir does not seek glory in danger without purpose. Touched by the wisdom and sadness of the Elder Race, he is shrewd in battle. This pack gives you the abilities needed to outlast Sauron’s forces and stand victorious at the battle’s end.
Text_CN: Faramir 不贪求没有目的的荣耀。受到长老一族智慧和悲伤的影响，他在战斗中聪明异常 这个卡包让你有能力和索伦比拼耐力并在最后获得战斗的胜利。
Text_FR: Faramir does not seek glory in danger without purpose. Touched by the wisdom and sadness of the Elder Race, he is shrewd in battle. This pack gives you the abilities needed to outlast Sauron’s forces and stand victorious at the battle’s end.

Text: Éowyn is renowned for her courage and compassion. With inner strength strong as tempered steel, she stands unflinching before even the greatest threats. This pack emphasizes cards that help your party defend against any threat no matter how numerous or mighty.
Text_CN: Éowyn 以勇气和同情心著称。内心无比强大如同钢铁，她在最大的威胁面前也不为动容 本卡包侧重让你能抵御强敌的卡牌。
Text_FR: Éowyn is renowned for her courage and compassion. With inner strength strong as tempered steel, she stands unflinching before even the greatest threats. This pack emphasizes cards that help your party defend against any threat no matter how numerous or mighty.

Text: Legolas has unmatched prowess as an archer. Employing acute senses and breathtaking agility, he outmaneuvers foes to defeat them before they even see him coming. This pack taps into Elvish tactics, using wits and swiftness to strike down enemies with deadly accuracy.
Text_CN: Legolas 作为射手有着无可比拟的威力。他感知敏锐，动如脱兔，在敌人看到他之前就能将敌人打败 本卡包侧着Elvish类的技巧，用你的智慧和决断去给与敌人致命一击吧。
Text_FR: Legolas has unmatched prowess as an archer. Employing acute senses and breathtaking agility, he outmaneuvers foes to defeat them before they even see him coming. This pack taps into Elvish tactics, using wits and swiftness to strike down enemies with deadly accuracy.

Text: Though he comes from humble beginnings, Samwise Gamgee rises to any challenge with unmatched bravery and determination. This pack is tailor-made for cleverness, helping you sneak past the watchful Eye of Sauron to claim victory through daring and stealth.

Text: The Lord of the Rings™: Living Card Game™ is still in active development. Features, cards, effects, and mechanics are subject to change for any number of reasons based on game play data and user feedback. If you run into any game play issues or bugs, or have any feedback, please let us know at our Steam Discussions. We appreciate your taking part in our early access development so that we can refine, balance, and improve the game. Now… on to Middle-earth and the adventures that await you there!
Text_CN: The Lord of the Rings™: Living Card Game™ is still in active development. Many features, cards, effects and mechanics are subject to change for any number of reasons based on game play data and user feedback. If you run into any game play issues or bugs, or have any feedback, please let us know at our Steam Discussions. We appreciate your taking part in our early access development so that we can refine, balance, and improve the game. Now… on to Middle-earth and the adventures that await you there!
Text_FR: Le Seigneur des Anneaux™, jeu de carte évolutif™ est toujours en cours de développement. Les fonctionnalités, cartes, effets et mécanismes de jeu sont susceptibles de changer pour un certain nombre de raisons basées sur les données de jeu et les retours des utilisateurs. Si vous rencontrez des problèmes ou des bugs dans le jeu, ou que vous avez des commentaires, merci de nous en informer sur nos Discussions Steam. Nous apprécions beaucoup que vous preniez part au développement grâce à l'accès anticipé, nous pourrons ainsi affiner, équilibrer et améliorer le jeu. Et maintenant... en route vers la Terre du Milieu et les aventures qui vous y attendent !

Text: You decide that the mission is too important to confront an unknown number of Orcs. You seek to bypass them by taking an alternate path, but the trail soon becomes increasingly overgrown and the forest floor covered in thick shrouds of webbing. You hear the skittering sound of many legs encroaching all around as it becomes clear you’ve stumbled into another spiders’ nest! You must fight past the chitinous horde if you wish to press on through Mirkwood this day.

Text: The King of Dale seeks an alliance with the Beornings and you have agreed to act as his envoy. To reach their lands, you must brave the dangers of Mirkwood Forest.
Your party camps for the night deep within Mirkwood. You awaken hours later from a troubled sleep to discover that giant spiders have captured your friends!
Though free of the giant spiders' lair, your party is lost in the dark forest. You must get your bearings if you hope to escape the vastness of Mirkwood.
Even as you leave the dangers of Mirkwood Forest behind, new threats arise as you make your way down the mighty Anduin River.
You have reached the land of the Beornings at last. But a new complication arises: Their leader, Grimbeorn the Old, is missing!

Shadows loom in Mirkwood Forest, threatening the lands that surround it. The King of Dale decides that the peoples living along the dark forest’s borders must unite against this menace. You agree to act as his envoy to the Beornings, reclusive Skin-changers who dwell in the Anduin Vale to the west under the rule of their chieftain, Grimbeorn the Old. This is a journey fraught with peril, since you must travel through Mirkwood itself. The Elf-path that crosses the forest’s northern reaches offers the safest route—but, while searching for this hidden path, you find yourself surrounded by servants of the growing darkness…

Orcs encroaching so far into Mirkwood? The King of Dale's concern was clearly justified, and your mission has taken on new urgency. You head down an overgrown trail to escape any other Orcs who might pursue. Senses alert to danger, you react swiftly when a new threat appears! Giant spiders drop from the trees to attack your party. You drive them back, only to discover that this was only a diversion—more spiders lunge from the snarled underbrush behind you! With horrifying speed, they wrap one of your friends in a silken cocoon and drag the captive off to be devoured. You cannot abandon your companion to such a fate.

You decide that the mission is too important to confront an unknown number of Orcs. You seek to bypass them by taking an alternate path, but the trail soon becomes increasingly overgrown and the forest floor covered in thick shrouds of webbing. You hear the skittering sound of many legs encroaching all around as it becomes clear you’ve stumbled into another spiders’ nest! You must fight past the chitinous horde if you wish to press on through Mirkwood this day.

You decide that the mission is too important to allow for delays. Returning to the Elf-path, you plan to confront the Orcs directly. You had heard no reports of Orc patrols before your recent encounter, after all, so you gamble that their numbers are not insurmountable.

Though you have broken through the spiders' lair, the confusion of battle has left you far from any trail. Searching tirelessly, you at last spot a path on the far side of a dark, unnatural-looking stream. As you look for a place to ford in this bleak place, an enormous creature emerges from the water to attack!

Your mission for the King of Dale has uncovered the presence of Orcs in Mirkwood Forest. Troubling news indeed. You make camp after a long day traveling ever further in this foul place. Sleep comes quickly to your tired eyes, but unsettling dreams disturb your rest—nightmares filled with bulbous eyes gleaming from the shadows and skittering legs echoing in the dark. Awakening in the wan pre-dawn light, you find it wasn't a dream at all. While you slept, the giant spiders of Mirkwood carried off your friends—and have returned to claim you as well! You must escape these vile creatures and seek out your companions at once!

Searching through the night, you find your friends at last. They are held within a dark glade, bound in cocoons made of strong webbed cords. You slip through the shadows, seemingly unnoticed by the spiders in their webs high above. However, as you raise your blade to cut your companions free, the creatures drop to the forest floor and attack!

You've managed to cut your companions loose, but the spiders are determined to recapture you. They spin giant webs from tree to tree, trapping you in their lair. You will have to sunder the thick strands in order to escape.

You hack through the spiders’ webs but advance only a short distance when a massive form emerges from the gloom. The largest spider you have ever seen blocks your way forward, while her many offspring gather behind you to cut off any retreat. There is no turning back. You must defeat Ungoliant's Spawn.

You have rescued your friends and escaped the spiders' lair, only to find yourself lost in the vastness of Mirkwood. Far from the relative safety of the Forest Road, the woods are a dark tangle of twisted trees. It is impossible to know the correct direction to travel within this wooded maze. If you are to find your way out and continue your mission for the King of Dale, you must first find some landmarks to get your bearings…

A stream winds its way through the twisted roots of ancient trees that crowd the riverbank. You follow the water's course as best you can, battling uneven terrain each step of the way. Though the stream should lead you from Mirkwood eventually, you wonder if a less arduous option can be found.

You stand atop a low hill, a sea of green spreading for miles in all directions. Scanning the horizon, you spy a faint trail of grey smoke rising in the distance. Smoke suggests civilization, though in Mirkwood there's no telling whether this means friend or foe. Alternately, you could keep searching for the Forest Road or some other path through these corrupted woods

Your patience has paid off. You see a tower in the distance that Gollum says is where they took the hobbit. The forest isn't done with you just yet though, a marshy section lays between you and the tower.

After a long, desperate search you find the trail at last. Overgrown and covered in animal tracks, this nonetheless promises to be your best means of reaching the Anduin Vale. You make good time at first, but soon realize that your presence has not gone unnoticed. While the path may ease travel, the roused denizens of Mirkwood shall make you fight for every step…

Navigating through the dense forest toward the smoke is no easy task, but at last you find the remains of an old Woodsmen village. Even more welcome to your eyes is the clear blue sky in the distance: you stand near the eaves of Mirkwood! Your relief is short-lived, however, as the village is overrun with Orcs! They spot your weary group, making it clear that you must fight to reach the Anduin Vale.

You stand at the shore of the Great River. To the south lies your destination: the land of the Beornings. Though the trials of Mirkwood Forest lay behind you pursuing Orcs remain a threat. You make haste along the riverbank looking for some means of shaking the Orcs off your trail. At last you spot a raft which should speed your journey. As you approach the craft a shadow falls before you: a fearsome Hill Troll looms up from behind a cluster of rocks! He lunges toward you his eyes gleaming with murderous intent…

Having defeated the Troll you scramble aboard the raft. Alas while you may have left the Orcs on the shore you face fresh danger as the Anduin carries you through a series of rapids! It will take all your skill to choose a safe course through the raging waters.

You steer the raft back to shore for a much-needed respite. Barely have you voiced your thanks at having firm ground beneath your feet when yet more Orcs come crashing through the underbrush! You decide that you have had enough of being hounded by these minions of the growing shadow. Weapons at the ready you confront the ambush head on…

Traversing the Anduin River has brought you from the Forest Gate south to the Beornings. You explain that yours is a mission of great urgency: you must speak with Grimbeorn the Old about what you have uncovered in Mirkwood, and share the offer of alliance from the King of Dale. The tribe of Skin-changers regrets that their chieftain is not present. He was last seen as a great bear, roaming south toward his stony outlook at the Carrock. You cannot afford to wait for his return. In order to find Grimbeorn, you will have to go after him at once…

You track Grimbeorn throughout the day, and shortly after sunset, you find evidence of a violent struggle. It is clear that the mighty Skin-changer faced a powerful foe… or foes. You see no further sign of Grimbeorn's tracks, either as man or bear. Instead, you discern the large, telltale footprints of Trolls. Fearing the worst, you follow the tracks to an impromptu camp set up under a rocky overhang. Grimbeorn lies in chains at the feet of some Trolls who cackle about the great feast they plan to make of him! You need hear no more—drawing your weapons, you rush to his rescue.

Freed from the chains, Grimbeorn claps you on the shoulder in thanks. You start toward the river, but he surprises you by heading deeper into the woods. "More Trolls lurk nearby," he growls. "We shall teach them the folly of crossing Grimbeorn the Old!" You dash after the Skin-changer, his shouts as easy to follow as his trail through the brush. Bursting into a moonlit clearing, you see Grimbeorn facing three massive Trolls. “A barrel of beer to any who bring me a Troll’s head!” he proclaims, lunging at the nearest foe. You will need to defeat the Trolls outright or find a way to keep them occupied until the sun rises!

As a guest of the Elves in Rivendell, Bilbo began to feel stretched, as if he were becoming thin in his old age. He longed for one last grand adventure while he still retained some measure of youthful vigor. During a visit by his old friend Gloin, Bilbo jumped at the chance to accompany the Dwarf once more to the Wilderlands and beyond to the Lonely Mountain of Erebor. Gloin led Bilbo through the mountain passes of the Misty Mountains, this time in summer and blissfully without any dangerous encounters. After descending from the mountains to the edge of Mirkwood, the pair entered the forest along the secret Elf-path and began the long journey toward the town of Dale. After two day's journey through Mirkwood, Gloin is setting up camp when Bilbo hears a curious noise and wanders off to investigate…

Bilbo races back to camp in order to warn his friend Gloin. As he enters the clearing, Bilbo finds his old Dwarf friend already locked in a valiant struggle to fend off more of the giant chittering spiders!

Before he fell, the Forest Protector told of a nest nearby. The spiders must be using it as a base from which to swarm the Elf-path. Bilbo and Gloin exhange a determined look. They well know the danger that these vile creatures pose. Other travelers must not fall to the spiders' depredations. The nest must be destroyed!

Although weary from your trevails, you summon the strength to cross the enchanted river. Having its dark waters between you and your pursuers brings some measure of relief, but you know well that further dangers lie ahead. You continue your journey, even more determined to warn the Beornings of the unrest stirring within Mirkwood Forest…

An unearthly shriek reverberates through the predawn woods as Ungoliant's Spawn thrashes about in her death throes. Even as her swollen carcass twitches its last, you spare no time to revel in victory. Eager to leave this place behind, you strike out deeper into the forest to continue your mission…

Against all odds, you have escaped Mirkwood Forest. Before you stretches the vales of Anduin, and the Misty Mountains beyond. The next leg of your journey lies to the south: the realm of the Beornings. Having seen firsthand the menace rising within Mirkwood, you know well the urgency to your mission. Still, you grant yourself a brief pause to gather your strength, the clear sky being a welcome change from your time under Mirkwood's dark canopy…

The battle is hard fought, but at last you stand triumphant. Even so, it is but a momentary victory. The strength of the Orcs' assault leaves little doubt that this was not a random attack: they intend to leave no witnesses to their presence in the region. Sparing a last look at the evidence of your defiance, you clamber back aboard the raft to complete your journey to the Beornings…

"Fine work," Grimbeorn says, looking upon the defeated Trolls. "I am in your debt." You explain that encountering him was not mere happenstance. The Beorning chieftain grows somber as you share the news of unrest along Mirkwood's borders, then gives a decisive nod. "Come; I would hear more of the King of Dale's offer. And there is that beer I promised!" You smile despite your weariness. Uniting the Beornings and Men of Dale against the forces marshaling within Mirkwood addresses but one threat of many. Yet, wherever your next adventure may lead, you take heart that the Free Peoples shall rise to the challenge…

Having fought past the Orc patrol, you move with haste down the Elf-path. The forest becomes increasingly bleak as you advance. Rotting leaves squelch beneath your feet and a fetid stench fills the air. Soon you discover the source of the foulness: a dark, unnatural-looking stream cuts across the path. You are looking for a means to cross when you hear the unmistakable guttural whoops and snarls of yet more Orcs. A harsh shout splits the air as the Orcs lunge at you in a frenzied assault!

You agree to act as his envoy to the Beornings, reclusive Skin-changers who dwell in the Anduin Vale to the west under the rule of their chieftain, Grimbeorn the Old. This is a journey fraught with peril, since you must travel through Mirkwood itself. The Elf-path that crosses the forest’s northern reaches offers the safest route—but, while searching for this hidden path, you find yourself surrounded by servants of the growing darkness…

Orcs encroaching so far into Mirkwood? The King of Dale's concern was clearly justified, and your mission has taken on new urgency. You head down an overgrown trail to escape any other Orcs who might pursue. Senses alert to danger, you react swiftly when a new threat appears! Giant spiders drop from the trees to attack your party. You drive them back, only to discover that this was only a diversion—more spiders lunge from the snarled underbrush behind you! With horrifying speed, they wrap one of your friends in a silken cocoon and drag the captive off to be devoured. You cannot abandon your companion to such a fate.

You decide that the mission is too important to confront an unknown number of Orcs. You seek to bypass them by taking an alternate path, but the trail soon becomes increasingly overgrown and the forest floor covered in thick shrouds of webbing. You hear the skittering sound of many legs encroaching all around as it becomes clear you’ve stumbled into another spiders’ nest! You must fight past the chitinous horde if you wish to press on through Mirkwood this day.

You decide that the mission is too important to allow for delays. Returning to the Elf-path, you plan to confront the Orcs directly. You had heard no reports of Orc patrols before your recent encounter, after all, so you gamble that their numbers are not insurmountable.

Though you have broken through the spiders' lair, the confusion of battle has left you far from any trail. Searching tirelessly, you at last spot a path on the far side of a dark, unnatural-looking stream. As you look for a place to ford in this bleak place, an enormous creature emerges from the water to attack!

Having fought past the Orc patrol, you move with haste down the Elf-path. The forest becomes increasingly bleak as you advance. Rotting leaves squelch beneath your feet and a fetid stench fills the air. Soon you discover the source of the foulness: a dark, unnatural-looking stream cuts across the path. You are looking for a means to cross when you hear the unmistakable guttural whoops and snarls of yet more Orcs. A harsh shout splits the air as the Orcs lunge at you in a frenzied assault!

Your mission for the King of Dale has uncovered the presence of Orcs in Mirkwood Forest. Troubling news indeed. You make camp after a long day traveling ever further in this foul place. Sleep comes quickly to your tired eyes, but unsettling dreams disturb your rest—nightmares filled with bulbous eyes gleaming from the shadows and skittering legs echoing in the dark. Awakening in the wan pre-dawn light, you find it wasn't a dream at all. While you slept, the giant spiders of Mirkwood carried off your friends—and have returned to claim you as well! You must escape these vile creatures and seek out your companions at once!

Searching through the night, you find your friends at last. They are held within a dark glade, bound in cocoons made of strong webbed cords. You slip through the shadows, seemingly unnoticed by the spiders in their webs high above. However, as you raise your blade to cut your companions free, the creatures drop to the forest floor and attack!

You've managed to cut your companions loose, but the spiders are determined to recapture you. They spin giant webs from tree to tree, trapping you in their lair. You will have to sunder the thick strands in order to escape.

You hack through the spiders’ webs but advance only a short distance when a massive form emerges from the gloom. The largest spider you have ever seen blocks your way forward, while her many offspring gather behind you to cut off any retreat. There is no turning back. You must defeat Ungoliant's Spawn.

You have rescued your friends and escaped the spiders' lair, only to find yourself lost in the vastness of Mirkwood. Far from the relative safety of the Forest Road, the woods are a dark tangle of twisted trees. It is impossible to know the correct direction to travel within this wooded maze. If you are to find your way out and continue your mission for the King of Dale, you must first find some landmarks to get your bearings…

A stream winds its way through the twisted roots of ancient trees that crowd the riverbank. You follow the water's course as best you can, battling uneven terrain each step of the way. Though the stream should lead you from Mirkwood eventually, you wonder if a less arduous option can be found.

You stand atop a low hill, a sea of green spreading for miles in all directions. Scanning the horizon, you spy a faint trail of grey smoke rising in the distance. Smoke suggests civilization, though in Mirkwood there's no telling whether this means friend or foe. Alternately, you could keep searching for the Forest Road or some other path through these corrupted woods

Your patience has paid off. You see a tower in the distance that Gollum says is where they took the hobbit. The forest isn't done with you just yet though, a marshy section lays between you and the tower.

After a long, desperate search you find the trail at last. Overgrown and covered in animal tracks, this nonetheless promises to be your best means of reaching the Anduin Vale. You make good time at first, but soon realize that your presence has not gone unnoticed. While the path may ease travel, the roused denizens of Mirkwood shall make you fight for every step…

Navigating through the dense forest toward the smoke is no easy task, but at last you find the remains of an old Woodsmen village. Even more welcome to your eyes is the clear blue sky in the distance: you stand near the eaves of Mirkwood! Your relief is short-lived, however, as the village is overrun with Orcs! They spot your weary group, making it clear that you must fight to reach the Anduin Vale.

You stand at the shore of the Great River. To the south lies your destination: the land of the Beornings. Though the trials of Mirkwood Forest lay behind you pursuing Orcs remain a threat. You make haste along the riverbank looking for some means of shaking the Orcs off your trail. At last you spot a raft which should speed your journey. As you approach the craft a shadow falls before you: a fearsome Hill Troll looms up from behind a cluster of rocks! He lunges toward you his eyes gleaming with murderous intent…

Having defeated the Troll you scramble aboard the raft. Alas while you may have left the Orcs on the shore you face fresh danger as the Anduin carries you through a series of rapids! It will take all your skill to choose a safe course through the raging waters.

Deciding that a direct route is the best means of losing your pursuers you steer the raft down a turbulent river channel. You soon realize this decision could spell your doom unless you can avoid the jumbles of rock and swirling eddies…

You steer the raft away from the rapids along the opposite shore far from your pursuers. Here the waters are calmer than before but the current remains swift and threatens to dash your flimsy craft upon rocks strewn along your course. You resolve to navigate your way to safety…

You steer the raft back to shore for a much-needed respite. Barely have you voiced your thanks at having firm ground beneath your feet when yet more Orcs come crashing through the underbrush! You decide that you have had enough of being hounded by these minions of the growing shadow. Weapons at the ready you confront the ambush head on…

Traversing the Anduin River has brought you from the Forest Gate south to the Beornings. You explain that yours is a mission of great urgency: you must speak with Grimbeorn the Old about what you have uncovered in Mirkwood, and share the offer of alliance from the King of Dale. The tribe of Skin-changers regrets that their chieftain is not present. He was last seen as a great bear, roaming south toward his stony outlook at the Carrock. You cannot afford to wait for his return. In order to find Grimbeorn, you will have to go after him at once…

You track Grimbeorn throughout the day, and shortly after sunset, you find evidence of a violent struggle. It is clear that the mighty Skin-changer faced a powerful foe… or foes. You see no further sign of Grimbeorn's tracks, either as man or bear. Instead, you discern the large, telltale footprints of Trolls. Fearing the worst, you follow the tracks to an impromptu camp set up under a rocky overhang. Grimbeorn lies in chains at the feet of some Trolls who cackle about the great feast they plan to make of him! You need hear no more—drawing your weapons, you rush to his rescue.

Freed from the chains, Grimbeorn claps you on the shoulder in thanks. You start toward the river, but he surprises you by heading deeper into the woods. "More Trolls lurk nearby," he growls. "We shall teach them the folly of crossing Grimbeorn the Old!" You dash after the Skin-changer, his shouts as easy to follow as his trail through the brush. Bursting into a moonlit clearing, you see Grimbeorn facing three massive Trolls. “A barrel of beer to any who bring me a Troll’s head!” he proclaims, lunging at the nearest foe. You will need to defeat the Trolls outright or find a way to keep them occupied until the sun rises!

After arriving at Beorn’s Hall, you’ve learned that the famous Bilbo Baggins was taken by Mirkwood Spiders mere hours ago. Without hesitation, you volunteer to find and retrieve the hobbit… hopefully before he’s consumed or some other deadly unpleasantness. And so you find yourself before Greenwood the Great, that the wary and the wise call Mirkwood. A sleeping evil once inhabited this land, but was purged many years ago. The forest has since known a period of peace and the return of wholesome life. As the shadows gather under the trees, you sense a foulness on the air. You fear evil may have returned to this realm.

Bilbo’s mind must have been clear during the first moments of his capture. You notice that he slid his sword along the undergrowth in the direction he was hauled away. As the spider’s poison immobilized him, he must have dropped Sting.

Encouraged, you venture into the shadowy green-gray wilderness that is Mirkwood.

The dead tree falls across the stream with a splintery crack. You use the fallen trunk to step across, careful to not slip. What could cause wild creatures to attack so? Perhaps the corrupted stream is their main source of water? 

As you jump off the trunk on the far side, a deep rumble greets you. For a brief moment you wonder what could make such a sound, but only for a brief moment. For out of the shadows shambles an enormous black bear. It roars.

The sound is staggering. It fills the air like a living thing, terrifying and primordial. The impact of the roar sends you reeling backwards, almost into the stream.

It charges. 

An avalanche of fur, teeth, and claws.

Before the monotony of the forest claws at you again, you come upon a sudden clearing. The sluggish breeze and wan grey light of the dell are a welcome change from the humid twilight of the forest. 

On the far side of the clearing you spy what you’ve been looking for: A group of large spiders, hovering over a tightly wound cocoon.

It’s time for a rescue!

Meanwhile...

Ufthak moves a hand to the pommel of his sheathed blade and other orcs step closer, raising their. Several smaller spiders flinch back, but the huge female stands her ground, glowering down at the insolent orc commander. For a long moment, there is complete silence.

Finally she chitters quietly at one of the nearby spiders. The minion moves quickly into the lair and drags Bilbo’s cocoon towards the gateway.

As the spider drags Bilbo’s cocoon before Ufthak, a small skinny creature flies out of the shadows, screeching “Preciouss” like a dying animal. It wraps its arms around Ufthak’s thick neck and bites his right ear. Black gore spills, and Ufthak’s furious roar joins the creature's tinny wail.

The screams echo through the trees and cobwebs.

It has gone from bad to worse. You ventured into Mirkwood to free a captured hobbit, but two of your party have themselves been captured.

Unwholesome strands break apart with snap and hiss as you cut and saw your way deeper into the lair. Mercifully, the web’s denizens are either absent or preoccupied, for you catch only brief glances of hairy bodies moving through the world of pale webbing and gray-green forest murk.

After slow and tiring progress, you come upon the nexus of the lair: An eldritch clearing devoid of webs, except for the great sinister shape of a dead tree wrapped densely in webs. Cocoons of many sizes hang from the dense webbing like depraved fruit. 

A few of the cocoons are of approximate size to your lost friends, one even moves fitfully. 

You move to open the cocoons, but the lair’s inhabitants finally have noticed your intrusion into their midst. Clacking spiders soon surround you, strangely in league with several orcs.

Meanwhile… Bruised and bloodied, the Creature whimpered at the cruelness of the world. It would have been killed had the orcses not been distracted by intruders in the Lady’s pantry. It had escaped into the tangled undergrowth and shrouded itself in shadows. From there it had seen Ufthak and his caravan depart. All that remained was the faint creaking of wagons fading into the gloom. The Lady remained before the gateway. When the clangor of battle from within the lair diminished, she began to shift her monsterous bulk. For shapes were moving within the webs, approaching the gateway. A strange and battle-worn band emerged, their faces paling in despair at the sight of the bloated monster that greeted them. The Lady of Bogwood, Broodmother of the Western Forest, descendant of great Ungoliant herself, now lost her composure and hissed with rage. The strangers had defiled her sanctum, her lair. Punishment was due.

It had escaped into the tangled undergrowth and shrouded itself in shadows. From there it had seen Ufthak and his caravan depart. Punishment was due.

After defeating a colony of great Mirkwood spiders, you discover that the eight-legged abominations had been gathering slaves for a host of orcs.  You believe that Bilbo Baggins was taken southwards by the orcs alongside the other victims.

Before deciding on your next courseof action, you capture an unpleasant creature lurking about your camp.  To your surprise, the creature knows the name "Baggins".

Being that the creature looks beaten and bruised, you decide to use kindness to extract information. However, after having been fed both food and gentle words, the creature remains throoughly unhelpful.

Before dawn, a more pressing problem materializes.  As dull grey seeps into the black edges of night, flying dark shapes begin to swoopunder the branches above you.  The shapes rapidly multiply and before long it is as if you've been caught inside a black whirlwind.
Before

You have neither time nor inclination to follow the strange Smeagol creature. Rather, by day or dark, you’ll chase down the orc caravan to free its captives, most especially Bilbo. You gather your packs and set off. 

Smeagol watches you go, his ghoulish eyes glowing a dull yellow. After a few moments, he slinks away into the trees muttering to himself. You wonder whether you’ll see the wretch again. You hope not.

The caravan is easily tracked and you make good time. Even so, the day is mostly spent before you hear the faint noise of rolling wheels ahead. Exultant to have reached your quarry, you hasten your steps, hoping to surprise and overwhelm the caravan’s rearguard.

In the excitement, you forget to consider the keen noses and sharp ears of goblins. As you round a copse of dead trees, you suddenly find yourself facing a group of orcs and goblins, alert and weapons ready. So much for surprise.

You decide that trusting Smeagol is worth the risk. If the creature knows of a way to get ahead of the caravan, you’ll have a significant advantage in rescuing Bilbo from the orcs.

As you follow Smeagol through the thick vegetation, the terrain begins to dip. Before long, the air is laced with mist and the soil grows spongy. You’re being led into a swamp.

“Swampses, yess. Cool nice swampses” Smeagol explains. “With frogses, fishes, and snakeses, precious. Tasty, gollum.” He pauses to crane his neck and sniff the air. “Smeagol looks to find right spot, masters. Safe way through mist and bogses.  Orcses and wagonses must go ‘round, you see. Missing tasty frogses, orcses are, gollum.”

Smeagol continues to sniffs and begins to crawls around the area looking for some landmark, some sign that he’s on the right path.

He suddenly smells something unexpected. The   rustle, the air hums, and unkind things emerge.

The sound of horns and ironshod feet clangor in the evening air. In the distance, you see torchlight flicker into life on the walls of what looks to be an old tower.  Cursing your own carelessness you dash into the thickets, orc horns blaring close behind. A fallen tree resting against mossy boulders serves as your hiding place.

You glimpse torchlit shapes of many enemies moving in your direction. By luck or fate, none come closer than a few hundred feet and you sigh in relief. After some time the horns stop braying, and scattered groups of orcs sullenly return through the forest, enthusiasm diminished.

Just as you begin to feel safe, you hear nearby rustling of leaves and the sound of voices. You recognize the grating speech of the enemy… and another voice. A whining, pitiful voice you’d hoped never to hear again.

Loathsome as Smeagol may be, something tells you to not stand idly by as the creature dragged to imprisonment and certain death.

You decide that trusting Smeagol is worth the risk. If the creature knows of a way to get ahead of the caravan, you’ll have a significant advantage in rescuing Bilbo from the orcs.

He suddenly smells something unexpected. The   rustle, the air hums, and unkind things emerge.

Approaching the Tower, the creature guides you through a hidden path along the base of the hill. There are a few small groups of Orcs here, but if you are quiet and strike quickly, you may be able to advance without raising the alarm…

Our heroes have escapes the Pit and make their way into the heart of the Tower, but Chieftain Ufthak learns of their intrusion and the defeat of his pet. He orders full mobilization of his forces, the intruders must not escape...

Barring the gate, you take a second to breathe, but your quest is not yet at an end. The creature is still lurking, and that gate will not hold back the Orcs forever. You must find Bilbo and make good an escape!

You stand at the shore of the Great River. To the south lies your destination: the Golden Wood of Lorien Though the trials of Mirkwood Forest lay behind you, the threat of pursuing Orcs remains. You make haste along the riverbank, looking for some means of shaking the Orcs off your trail. At last, you spot a raft which should speed your journey. As you approach the craft, a shadow falls before you: a fearsome Hill Troll looms up from behind a cluster of rocks! He lunges toward you, his eyes gleaming with murderous intent…

Having defeated the Troll, you scramble aboard the raft. Alas, while you may have left the Orcs on the shore, you face fresh danger as the Anduin carries you through a series of rapids! It will take all your skill to choose a safe course through the raging waters.
Having reached a shallower part of the river, the raft is stuck on a sandbar in a fordable area of the river. Shallow water is good for Orcs, not so good for you.

You dislodge the raft from the shallows and press on, hounded on the right side of the river now by the Orcs. It is only a short distance to Lorien, but there is no way you can make it there without a battle. Steeling yourselves, you beach the raft and charge towards the forest.
Steal the key via pickpocketing, or defeat the guards until you find a key.

As darkness thickens, orange light from orc fires bathe the dilapidated walls of the ruined tower. Your spirits sink as you witness the prisoners, still cocooned, carried into the old building through a set of heavy doors. Orcs and goblins seem to be everywhere.

How will you get to Bilbo? And if you do, how will you get away? You decide to chance entering the tower through a small sortie door near the tower’s eastern side. descending into boglands below from the tower’s base

As you sneak nearer the sortie door, a group of orcs emerge from the door. One locks the door behind him with a large key, and the band moves to continue their patrol. 

Hidden in the shadows of the broken curtain wall, you wonder how you’ll get into the tower unnoticed.
Smegol is playing with a strange device while you hunt for Bilbo

After sneaking through the sortie door, you emerge into a huge chamber full of reeking orc supplies, fallen stones, and intruding vegetation. A number of large chains emerge from small floor openings along the sides of the chamber, terminating into a large iron box bolted to the far wall. The box bristles with rusty hooks and mechanical wheels.

You slide quietly through the room, desperate to avoid attention. You peek into the chamber’s connecting rooms, hoping to find where the orcs are storing their prisoners.

Steps are suddenly heard on the flagstones, coming in your direction. 

After a few moments, an orc enters the chamber to rummage through supplies. The light of its torch happens to catch one of your buckles, and the orc glances lazily in your direction. For a second, the orc seem to not understand what it is seeing, but recognition sets in quickly. 


You’re about to be discovered.
Gain +1 every time another Orc is defeated
There was a rush of hoarse laughter, like the fall of sliding stones into a pit; amid the clamour a deep voice was raised in command. —The Fellowship of the Ring
Exhaust a random Hero through the end of next round

Mirkwood is an implacable foe impossible to defy. It wears down all who would venture within its dark and twisted confines. You and your companions are no different. Though you have all drawn upon the full measure of your abilities, it is not enough. Exhaustion has sapped your very will.

The Lord of the Rings Living Card Game is a narrative adventure game in which you form your own fellowships of Heroes to stand against Sauron, the source of evil that threatens all of Middle-earth during the Third Age.
     In this game, Sauron is an active opponent. He directs the actions of his forces and plays his own hand of cards against your Heroes. He influences everything you encounter, from Enemies you face to Objectives needed to complete each Quest.
     This tutorial guides you through the basics of gameplay. First, let's look at the game environment…

While there is more to discover that will help you on your Quest, you have learned the fundamentals that will carry you through this battle. It is down to you, now—defeat the King Spider, destroy the nest, and win the day!

"I am starting to feel the weight of my years," Bilbo told his old friend Glóin. The dwarf was visiting him in Rivendell, where Bilbo had taken up residence. After his eleventy-first birthday party, Bilbo had left his home to his nephew, Frodo, and accepted an invitation from Elrond to live as a guest of the elves. However, pleasant as this next chapter in his life was, he began to feel a growing ache in his bones.
     "I want to explore again, before I grow too old to do so. Just a short trip to see the old places again. Perhaps even the Lonely Mountain."
     "Your words stir my heart as well," Glóin replied. "It would be an honor to oblige the esteemed Burglar Baggins in one last adventure."

Text:
Leaving Glóin to enjoy the famous mead purchased during a stop at the House of Beorn, Bilbo passed into the twilight landscape beyond their campsite. Despite weary feet and a full stomach, the old hobbit longed for an evening stroll.  
     He and Glóin had traveled without incident through the Misty Mountains and across the Anduin, and had just entered eaves of Mirkwood along the Old Forest Road. It was a safe route, without even the rumor of Goblins for many seasons. Yet the journey had done little to quell the restlessness within Bilbo. Past adventures and distant friends lay heavy on his heart. And the secret longing, the deep dull ache that would never abate entirely, had grown stronger in recent days.
     Lost in memory, Bilbo wandered through a clearing illuminated by the last rays of the setting sun. He came out of his reverie as something stirred in the tall bushes nearby. Assuming his traveling companion had decided to join him for a stroll, Bilbo turned with a greeting on his lips.
     Alas, what emerged was not Glóin…

Text:
For days, a strange pull had drawn the creature toward the edge of the forest.
     Desire drove it on. And hunger. And longing. Though it missed the cool air and precious darkness under stone, it had roamed the Wilderlands for years. Relentlessly searching, hunting… craving.
     A sudden burst of noise nearby drew its attention. The creature slid through the shadows to investigate.
     Peering from the trees, its ancient heart began to beat rapidly. For there it was, upon the trail… the thief. The forever cursed.
     At last.
     Baggins.

Text:
Weariness forgotten, Bilbo raced back toward camp. The snakes had come from that direction, agitated by something. Something that had driven them away. Something that might pose a danger to Glóin.
     Bilbo cursed himself for being lulled into complacency. This was Mirkwood, after all. Though it had known peace in recent years, its dark nature was unchanged. For each danger revealed, another lurked in the shadows.
     Rounding a bend in the trail, Bilbo's suspicions were confirmed: Illuminated by the campfire, his old friend was locked in a valiant struggle against giant spiders…

Text_FR:
Weariness forgotten, Bilbo raced back toward camp. The snakes had come from that direction, agitated by something. Something that had driven them away. Something that might pose a danger to Glóin.
     Bilbo cursed himself for being lulled into complacency. This was Mirkwood, after all. Though it had known peace in recent years, its dark nature was unchanged. For each danger revealed, another lurked in the shadows.
     Rounding a bend in the trail, Bilbo's suspicions were confirmed: Illuminated by the campfire, his old friend was locked in a valiant struggle against giant spiders…

Text:
The creature hesitated.
     It would have struck without mercy, had not that filthy dwarf been with Baggins. The creature feared the strength of dwarvses. Fortunately, it knew of a safer—crueler—way to snare its prey.
     The creature had made friends in the forest. It had learned their chittering tongue, and they had helped each other in dark deeds over the years.
     Without even a whisper of sound, the creature slipped away beneath the shadowed boughs. It would plead with the lady of the nearby brood. Tasty flesh it would offer her.
     In turn, the creature desired only a tiny thing. The smallest of things.
     A trinket.

Text:
Before he fell, the Forest Protector told of a nest nearby. The spiders must be using it as a base from which to swarm the road. 
     Bilbo and Glóin exhanged a determined look. They well knew the danger that these vile creatures posed. Others must not fall to the spiders' depredations. The nest must be destroyed!
     Ranging into the woods, the compaions soon came across the sound of battle. It appears that they were not the only travelers being waylayed by the resurgent spiders.

Text:
While the party was focused on destroying the spiders' nest, a massive spider lunged from the shadows to capture Bilbo and steal him away! Glóin and Arwen recognized that the beast was a spawn of Ungoliant, a spider of tremendous power. They realized they must return to the nearby Beornings to organize a rescue party for Bilbo.

Their mission clear, the companions returned to the Hall of Beorn with the greatest of haste.

Text:
You have completed the prologue, but your adventure has only just begun. 
     Gather your own fellowship and begin the first Campaign, The Shadow's Reach, to rescue Bilbo!

Text:
You begin to search for clues as to which direction the spiders took Bilbo.

There are ample signs of recent struggle in the small glade, and several of the hobbit’s possessions are strewn about. After a few moments, you notice a gleam of metal on the forest floor a little way into the woods. Perhaps a sign? 

You’re about to investigate as several giant spiders creep into the glade. They don’t seem at all interested in assisting the search. Quite the contrary.

<line-height=100%><size=200%>H</size>eavy footsteps echo down the stairwell, growing louder with each step. A large shadow falls across the flagstones as a mighty orc enters the chamber. Silhouetted by torchlight, Chieftain Ufthak snarls a command to his eager minions. The battle is joined!
Restore every Enemy to full . If no health is restored, add 2 Orcs

The orcs were not expecting an assault on the tower. You use your surprise to full advantage, hammering away at your foes. Then it's your turn to be surprised—you expected your furious attack to drop all who stood before you, yet still they stand.

Gollum's Help
Do you ignore Gollum, or listen to Gollum...

You dislodge the raft from the shallows and press on, hounded on the right side of the river now by the Orcs. It is only a short distance to Lorien, but there is no way you can make it there without a battle. Steeling yourselves, you beach the raft and charge towards the forest.
Play Shaft of Sunlight and say things!
Deal 1 damage when attacked. Gain +1 when Giant Worm attacks
WHICH 	way to go you say

While the companions were focused on destroying the spiders' nest, a massive spider charged from the shadows. Moving with incredible speed despite its size, the monstrous creature pounced upon Bilbo! Arwen and Glóin rushed to defend their friend, but it was too late. The spider spun sticky silken cords around the hobbit even as it bounded away to vanish into the depths of the forest.
but it took some time to do

Smeagol has betrayed you. Somehow the villain has triggered the mechanism, causing one side of the floor to abruptly drop. Your legs slip violently forward as you flail down the steep angle. Amidst the cacophony of sliding rubble, supplies, and orc bodies, you catch sight of Smeagol. Dangling from one of the chains, he gleefully watches you disappear.

“Goodbyeses, masters!” he shrieks. “Smeagol findses Baggins, gollum. Precious is mine! It is Miiine!”

His shrill voice fades as you slide over the lip of the impossibly tilted floor and drop into a rancid darkness. For a moment you’re adrift in blackness, then you meet wet ground with a bone-rattling mucky slap. Debris and materials continue to fall around you for a several seconds. 

With a groan, the chain rolls again as the ceiling retreats to its former position. You push your hands against the wet ground, rising your bruised self up to study your new situation.

Meanwhile… The Lady and her brood are gathered at the edge of their lair. A band of orcs and goblins have emerged from the trees. Some heave empty wagons, others carry torches. A large torch-bearing orc tromps closer to the Lady. “The moon is full, spidey. Ufthak comes to collect!” he snarls. The Lady chitters at her lieutenants who rush back into the webs. They return bearing web-wrapped cocoons, depositing them before Ufthak. Goblins rush to gather the cocoons, loading them into carts. As the last of the many cocoons is loaded, a hooded goblin begins screeching at the orc captain, pointing to a parchment full of hash marks. Ufthak studies the yelling goblin for a moment, then blinks and pivots back to the Lady. “We one short, leggy!” The orc’s grainy voice is mild, but laced with the promise of violence. “Cold masters don’t like... short. Ufthak don’t like... short. We had... deal!”.

You have successfully gotten Bilbo to safety in Lorien. He will need time to recover from his ordeal before he moves along on his travels to Dale. You however, have adventures ahead of you investigating the information gathered on your adventure...

The forest floor is awash with the marks of ironshod feet and wagon tracks. You begin slowly to make sense of the situation: The spiders are gathering slaves for a host of orcs, intended for some devilry yet to be uncovered.

Deep in thought, you hike a sensible distance from the spider’s lair to camp for the night, unsure of what to do next.

As the shadows coalesce into night, you hear someone, something, creeping through the undergrowth beyond the firelight. After silent glances amongst each other, a few nods, and a quick dash, the creeper is quickly caught. 

Shrieking like a stuck pig, it bites and flails about with surprising strength. Its energy soon spent, the creature curls itself into a sobbing ball on the ground. You catch a few words in its rambling litany of self-pity.  The creature repeatedly refers to a “precious” and... a name. Could it be? How that name would to be known to the wretch, you cannot guess.

For the creature is muttering about “Baggins”.
You've defied every problem along the way and saved Bilbo. Now you must make good on your escape though...

Meanwhile… A small cocoon is hauled before the Lady. “Eats it, m’lady. Scrumptious it is, tasty sweet.” the skinny Creature squeals in pleasure, jumping to and fro on arms and legs as if a spider himself. The Creature gives the cocoon a kick. “False it is, Baggins. Trickster, thief, cheater. Gollum. Eats it, eeeeats it!”. The enormous female spider-thing moves to hover over the cocoon, spear-sized pinchers emerge slowly from its dripping maw. “Suck it to boneses, m’lady! No dryingness needed. Not like tough dwarvses or tricksy elvses. Sweet and juicy, hobbit is. Just leave clothses, m’Lady. Gollum. My Preciousss is in its pocketses.". The spider monstrosity is about to delve into her meal, when a sudden noise is heard from the edge of the lair. Flapping its hands nervously and bobbing its scrawny neck, the Creature pleads “Don’t listen to woodsy noises, m’lady. Eat, eaat, while hobbit is warmses.” Someone has arrived, and the spiders move to greet them.

Although weary from your trevails, you summon the strength to cross the enchanted river. Having its dark waters between you and your pursuers brings some measure of relief, but you know well that further dangers lie ahead. You continue your journey, even more determined to warn the Beornings of the unrest stirring within Mirkwood Forest…

Having rescued your friend and left the spiders’ lair, you must decide upon your next course of action. Though you have no idea how many Orcs patrol these woods, their presence threatens the success of your mission. Do you stay off the main path and find an alternate route around them, or confront them directly in hopes of pushing on quickly?

An unearthly shriek reverberates through the predawn woods as Ungoliant's Spawn thrashes about in her death throes. Even as her swollen carcass twitches its last, you spare no time to revel in victory. Eager to leave this place behind, you strike out deeper into the forest to continue your mission…

Against all odds, you have escaped Mirkwood Forest. Before you stretches the vales of Anduin, and the Misty Mountains beyond. The next leg of your journey lies to the south: the realm of the Beornings. Having seen firsthand the menace rising within Mirkwood, you know well the urgency to your mission. Still, you grant yourself a brief pause to gather your strength, the clear sky being a welcome change from your time under Mirkwood's dark canopy…

The battle is hard fought, but at last you stand triumphant. Even so, it is but a momentary victory. The strength of the Orcs' assault leaves little doubt that this was not a random attack: they intend to leave no witnesses to their presence in the region. Sparing a last look at the evidence of your defiance, you clamber back aboard the raft to complete your journey to the Beornings…

"Fine work," Grimbeorn says, looking upon the defeated Trolls. "I am in your debt." You explain that encountering him was not mere happenstance. The Beorning chieftain grows somber as you share the news of unrest along Mirkwood's borders, then gives a decisive nod. "Come; I would hear more of the King of Dale's offer. And there is that beer I promised!" You smile despite your weariness. Uniting the Beornings and Men of Dale against the forces marshaling within Mirkwood addresses but one threat of many. Yet, wherever your next adventure may lead, you take heart that the Free Peoples shall rise to the challenge…
Lying on the forest floor is a small elven blade, beautiful, strong and light. This must be Bilbo's sword, Sting. A valuable treasure.
Look through Bilbo's pack to find some supplies

In the tall grasses at the edge of the glade, you uncover one of Bilbo’s travel packs. Within, you’re pleased to confirm the hobbit never left home without a bit of provision, not even on an evening stroll.
His beard, very long and forked, was white, nearly as white as the snow-white cloth of his garments. —The Fellowship of the Ring

For hours you delve into the menacing forest. Thorny undergrowth and sticky crawlers grab at you as if with minds of their own.

A subtle change in the echo of the wood heralds a change in scenery, and you soon come upon a dark gurgling stream.

While the watery smells and soothing sounds relax you, you’ve been warned not to trust any water in Mirkwood––save for that gathered from fresh rain.

The spiders must have crossed the stream by traversing the canopies above, but how will you cross? A nearby dead tree may be the answer!

You attempt to push at its dry trunk, hoping for it to fall and bridge the stream. Unfortunately, your huffing and puffing attracts the local wildlife.
Exhaust any Character that is damaged by this card

Meanwhile… The Lady and dozens of her brood have gathered before a gateway at the edge of their lair. A great number of orcs and shuffling goblins have emerged from trees Many of the goblins are heaving empty carts, clunking over roots and stones. Four of the orcs tromp closer to stand before the great bulk of the Lady. Several nearby spiders shy nervously from orc’s torches. “The moon is full, spidey. Ufthak comes to collect!”. The captain of the orcs growl in a deep voice.. The Lady leans to chitter at her lieutenants, and a number of them skitter into the webs on her bidding. Soon the spiders return, each bearing a cocoon which they deposit before the orcs. Goblins rush to gather the cocoons, loading them into carts. As the last of the cocoons are loaded, goblins begin to pull at the carts. With clanking and bouncing, the loaded caravan begins its return journey south. A hooded goblin approaches the orc leader in a panic, waving a parchment full of crude hashmarks. Pointing at the parchment, it screeches at Graguk in its foul language. The great orc thunderously roars at the departing caravan “Halt! Ufthak says halt!”

You recall the old story of Bilbo singing giant spiders to distraction. How did it go now? Ah, yes, you remember. Old fat spider spinning in a tree! Old fat spider can’t see me! Attercop! Attercop! Won't you stop, Stop your spinning and look for me!

Gloin’s conscience gnaws at him in the comfort of Beorn’s house. Bilbo was abducted while strolling to meet him, Gloin, because he’d been late arriving. To make matters worse, a group of strangers were now risking their lives over his failure. Something in him gives, and Gloin makes up his mind. Age be damned! He knows enough of woodlore to find the trail of the brave strangers, and his axe is sharp enough to hew a few more spiders.

After recovering, Wilelk thanks you profusely. Over the past few months, he tells you, a number of tribesmen have gone mysteriously absent. He suspects they’ve fallen prey to similar circumstances, but offers no explanation as to why the great spiders have suddenly become so daring.

Afraid to return home through the forest alone, Wilelk offers to join you and suggests which direction the spiders were taking him. 

Somewhere under the neverending trees before you, an old hobbit awaits rescue or doom.
"But you do not stand alone." —Elrond, The Fellowship of the Ring

As you make your way through the dense forest, a sudden shriek is heard. 

Praying hobbits to be incapable of so pitiful a sound, you move quickly to investigate its source. You can’t help but feel that Bilbo and his captors have a part to play in the sudden din.

Your suspicions mount as the forest show signs of giant spiderwebs. At first, only a few thick strands are seen between canopy and trunk, but the webbing quickly grows denser. Before long the sticky ropes are thick enough to block your path. 

About to hack away at the webbing, you sense a subtle shift in the shadows and glance up.

Only a few feet above your head, the myriad glare of malicious eyes observe you. Pinchers drip with ichor. Hairy bloated bodies tremble with anticipation.

Weak from the spider's poison, Wilelk doesn't see the blow coming. He collapses onto the forest floor. 

You gain newfound respect for the hardiness of the Beornings, when you realise the man is still breathing.
Breaking open the cocoon, you find one of your lost heroes inside.
Opening the cocoon, this is not your friend! You jump back as an Orc lashes out at you.
Opening the cocoon, you don't find who you were looking for.

Ready a Character.
Deal it 1 damage
The Ulahid herbs are reknowned for their ability to awaken even the deepest sleeper to an instantly awake state, though the headache that accompanies the smell is equally reknowned.
Gain a vial of Mirkwood Water
The water of the corrupted stream has potent soporific qualities. You decide to bottle some of it. Perhaps it will be useful later?

There is one stream there, I know, black and strong which crosses the path. That you should neither drink of, nor bathe in; for I have heard that it carries enchantment and a great drowsiness and forgetfulness. -The Hobbit
You come across some wild honey gathered by the bees of the forest. Thinking quickly, you scoop up some of the sweet substance and toss it in the path of the bears to distract them.
Despite typically being solitary creatures, the sound of your conflict draws in even more bears who are stalking you as a group!

Another roar bellows close by. The thought of dealing with yet another of Mirkwood’s great bruins brings you near despair. Dumbfounded, you witness the new arrival trample past you to gore one of your enemies with its fearful maw. As you’ve seen this shade of fur before, you realize that Grimbeorn, the chieftain of the Beornings, has come to do battle with Kirus, enemy of the true wild.

As you finish putting down the last of the giant spiders, you turn to your companions to see them being wrapped quickly in cocoons by spiders. With a cry of alarm you charge to their rescue, but not before being blocked by more incoming spiders. You must rescue them, quickly!
With a pained grunt, Chieftain Ufthak falls back shouting at his minions to kill you all. You have a feeling you haven't seen the last of him.
With the giant snake defeated, you extricate yourself from the marshy ground and make your way stealthily towards the tower to find a way in.
After defeating the giant snake, you extricate yourself from the damp and nasty marsh and make your way stealthily towards the tower. You must find a way inside...
You slip away into the shadows, avoiding the Orcs that are now searching the forest for your group. You still must find a way inside however...
Though crude and cheaply forged, the weapons of fallen Orcs serve as good backup weapons. Your party picks over the bodies salvage what you can.
A flat topped hill looks like the opportune place to make a stand. If you can take the high ground, your enemies will have a hard time taking you by force.
Marsh Adder loses Block until End of Round
Exhaust a Hero. That Hero does not ready during the next Upkeep
Deal 2 damage to each Character with Stealth
1 Hazard enters play. Restore 1 to Strange Mechanism
Apply 1 Progress to Intruders in the Tower
